To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

At the end of the ’00s, Peter Hook wasn’t sure what he was going to do.

In 2007, the bassist announced he quit New Order, the highly influential band he co-founded in 1980, following the end of his first group, Joy Division, whose lead singer Ian Curtis died by suicide on the eve of their first U.S. tour.

Hook’s other band, Monaco, was in limbo after their self-titled 2000 record sank due to record company indifference. He formed Freebass with fellow bassists Gary “Mani” Mounfield (the Stone Roses) and Andy Rourke (the Smiths), but they broke up before their 2010 debut album hit the shelves.

That’s when Hook formed yet another group, Peter Hook and the Light, with his son Jack. Hook’s goal? “I set out to do something — God willing, the grim reaper willing — and I will be fulfilling my dream of playing every song written and recorded by Joy Division and New Order,” he said during a recent phone interview from his home in Manchester.

Hook has since spent the decade on the road, playing two albums in full on each tour: Joy Division’s “Unknown Pleasure” and “Closer”; New Order’s “Movement” and “Power, Corruption and Lies”; and “Low-Life” and “Brotherhood.”

In 2016, Hook tackled “Substance,” the name of compilations from both Joy Division and New Order. The former collects the group’s singles and B-sides, while the latter includes extended remixes of New Order’s first seven years of singles. Released in 1987, New Order’s “Substance” remains the band’s best-selling album in the U.S. and served as an entry point to the group for a generation of fans.

The U.S. “Substance” tour, which hit Minneapolis’ First Avenue in October 2016, did so well that promoters asked for an encore. So before Hook debuts New Order’s “Technique” and “Republic” this fall in England, he’s back in the States with a return trip to First Avenue tonight.

Here’s what else the 62-year-old had to share about his music, his career and his future.

On how he developed his distinctive style of playing:

“What happened was, I started to play lead lines because my equipment was so poor. I couldn’t hear myself if I played low. Ian Curtis loved it, and it enabled Barney (singer/guitarist Bernard Sumner) to play lead the way he did.”

On the decision to perform his band’s albums in full:

“It began with the 30th anniversary of Ian Curtis’ death. I wanted to celebrate him. I had no contact with Barney and (drummer Stephen Morris) at that point. We had finished on a particularly bad note. And then they went behind my back and everybody knows what happened with that regard. (New Order hired bassist Tom Chapman to replace Hook.)

“We were not trying to pretend to be Joy Division. I wanted to find a way to celebrate Curtis without being a pale imitation. And when we played the albums, they sounded completely different live. We were much faster, much edgier.”

On whether he heard “Music Complete,” the 2015 album New Order recorded with Chapman:

“Yeah, I did. Bernard is a particularly talented songwriter, but it sounded a bit more like his solo work rather than the magic of New Order.”

On what it’s like to hear Chapman playing his signature bass lines:

“That geezer doesn’t play like me. I’ve listened to him, he doesn’t play my lines — successfully, I’d say. I’m glad that I get to play them correctly, just how I wrote them. (Chapman) doesn’t really bother me, but if I wasn’t performing with the Light, it would bother me a hell of a lot more. You can listen to us both and judge accordingly.”

On playing the “Substance” albums live:

“There’s a huge contrast between the two, which is nice. The Joy Division one has much lesser-known tracks, but it goes down just as well if not better. New Order’s music is quite challenging and I don’t get the option to drop the difficult tracks. I have to play them all. But it’s very rewarding and I’m glad that we are so different than the current incarnation of my old group.”

On the possibility of new solo music:

“As I get older, I do struggle with the whole concept of working for nothing. Pottsy (Monaco’s David Potts) and I have talked repeatedly about doing another Monaco record. I do feel guilty in that regard, I suppose. (New Order’s original record label boss) Tony Wilson always used to say your best single you’re ever going to write is your next one.”

IF YOU GO

What: Peter Hook and the Light with DJ Jake Rudh

When: 7 p.m. Monday

Where: First Avenue, 701 First Ave. N., Minneapolis

Tickets and info: $25; 612-332-1775 or first-avenue.com
